title: Artist Talk: Jacqueline Humphries
hero_caption: Courtesy of the artist and Greene Naftali, New York. Photo by Martha Fleming-Ives.
short_description: By the mid-1980s painting had been declared “dead” several times over. But for the contemporary painter Jacqueline Humphries, the medium became a “rogue practice”; however risky, it has remained her foundation.
list_description: By the mid-1980s painting had been declared “dead” several times over. But for the contemporary painter Jacqueline Humphries, the medium became a “rogue practice”; however risky, it has remained her foundation.
description:
By the mid-1980s painting had been declared “dead” several times over, but for the painter Jacqueline Humphries, it was a “rogue practice.” The medium has remained her foundation throughout her career. “Painting can adapt to anything,” she has said.

Join us in learning how the artist has adapted to—and subverted—what a painting can be with reference to both art history and cutting-edge technologies.
